cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
In which film did Johnny Depp play a policeman called Ichabod Crane?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To answer the question, I need to recall the films in which Johnny Depp has acted. The character Ichabod Crane is a well-known figure from Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow." Johnny Depp portrayed this character in a film adaptation directed by Tim Burton. The film is known for its gothic style and unique interpretation of the classic tale. 

Answer: Sleepy Hollow

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
In which film did Johnny Depp play a policeman called Ichabod Crane?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- Johnny Depp as Ichabod Crane: Crane is a quirky, yet sympathetic constable infatuated with integrating modern science into police procedures, but is squeamish at the sight of blood and bugs. Depp is humorous in his portrayal of the character.\n', 'While Johnny Depp was Burton\'s first choice for the role of Ichabod Crane, Paramount required him to consider Brad Pitt, Liam Neeson and Daniel Day-Lewis. Depp was cast in July 1998 for his third collaboration with Burton. The actor wanted Ichabod to parallel Irving\'s description of the character in the short story. This included a long prosthetic snipe nose, huge ears, and elongated fingers. Paramount turned down his suggestions, and after Depp read Tom Stoppard\'s rewrite of the script, he was inspired to take the character even further. "I always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl," Depp explained. He did not wish to portray the character as a typical action star would have, and instead took inspiration by Angela Lansbury\'s performance in "Death on the Nile". "It\'s good," Burton reasoned, "because I\'m not the greatest action director in the world, and he\'s not the greatest action star." Depp modeled Ichabod\'s detective personality from Basil Rathbone in the 1939 "Sherlock Holmes" film series. He also studied Roddy McDowall\'s acting for additional influence. Burton added that "the idea was to try to find an elegance in action of the kind that Christopher Lee or Peter Cushing or Vincent Price had." Christina Ricci, who worked with producer Scott Rudin on "The Addams Family", was cast as Katrina Van Tassel. "Sleepy Hollow" also reunited Burton with Jeffrey Jones (from "Beetlejuice" and "Ed Wood") as Reverend Steenwyck, Christopher Walken (Max Shreck in "Batman Returns") as the Hessian Horseman, Martin Landau ("Ed Wood") in a cameo role, and Hammer veteran Michael Gough (Alfred in Burton\'s "Batman" films), whom Burton tempted out of retirement. The Hammer influence was further confirmed by the casting of Christopher Lee in a small role as the Burgomaster who sends Crane to Sleepy Hollow.\n', 'BULLET::::- Constable Ichabod Crane serves as the protagonist in the 1999 film adaptation of "Sleepy Hollow", directed by Tim Burton and starring Johnny Depp. In this interpretation, he is a New York City policeman with an interest in Forensic science sent to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a series of grisly murders to prove the merits of his style of the investigation after he argues against the police\'s current methods. As in the original story, his horse is named Gunpowder. Ichabod\'s most notable traits in the movie include an ahead-of-his-time liking for post-mortem examinations, deduction, and scientific methods, as well as his being very quirky, skittish, and being disturbed by death and blood, despite his occupation. His backstory is also explored: when he was seven his mother, an "innocent child of Nature" was "murdered to save her soul" by his father, "a Bible black tyrant behind a mask of righteousness" which led to a loss of faith for him. It is Ichabod who finally releases the Hessian Headless Horseman (Christopher Walken) from the control of Lady van Tassel (Miranda Richardson), whom the Horseman takes to Hell with him. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) is seen at the end of the movie going back to New York with Ichabod, along with a boy who helped him in the investigation. Brom Bones (Casper Van Dien), who at one point does disguise himself as the Horseman and throws a pumpkin at Ichabod, is killed by the real Horseman halfway in the film.\n', 'Depp\'s next venture with Burton was the period film "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), in which he played Ichabod Crane opposite Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken. For his performance, Depp took inspiration from Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall and Basil Rathbone. He stated that he "always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl."\n', 'BULLET::::- Ichabod Crane is also featured in the 2013 episodic video game, "The Wolf Among Us", developed and produced by Telltale Games. In the game, Crane (voiced by Roger L. Jackson) is the deputy mayor of Fabletown, a secret community of magical, fairytale beings who were exiled from their Homelands centuries ago and forced to live in the world of mundane humans. In episodes 2 through three, Crane was revealed to have been soliciting prostitutes and using a magic spell to make them look like his assistant Snow White; Sheriff Bigby Wolf and Snow arrest Crane for this and embezzling Fabletown\'s money to pay for them, but Crane is then kidnapped by the minions of the Crooked Man, the crime lord Crane owes money to.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

The passages provided contain several key pieces of information that may be unfamiliar or provide additional context to the model regarding Johnny Depp's portrayal of Ichabod Crane in the film "Sleepy Hollow." Here’s an analysis of the relevant content:

1. **Character Background and Traits**:
   - Ichabod Crane is described as a "quirky, yet sympathetic constable" who is "infatuated with integrating modern science into police procedures." This highlights the character's unique approach to law enforcement, which contrasts with traditional methods. His squeamishness at the sight of blood and bugs adds a layer of complexity to his character, making him more relatable and human.

2. **Film Context**:
   - The film "Sleepy Hollow," directed by Tim Burton and released in 1999, is an adaptation of Washington Irving's short story. The adaptation takes creative liberties, presenting Ichabod Crane as a New York City policeman sent to investigate a series of grisly murders. This modernized setting and the character's forensic interests are significant deviations from the original story, which may not be widely known.

3. **Character Development**:
   - The passages mention Ichabod's backstory, including a traumatic childhood event where his mother was murdered by his father. This backstory is crucial for understanding Ichabod's character motivations and his loss of faith, which adds depth to his role in the film.

4. **Collaboration and Inspiration**:
   - The passages detail Johnny Depp's collaboration with Tim Burton and his inspirations for the character, including performances by Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall, and Basil Rathbone. This context provides insight into Depp's artistic choices and how he shaped the character of Ichabod Crane, moving away from a typical action star portrayal.

5. **Supporting Characters**:
   - The film features notable characters such as Katrina Van Tassel (played by Christina Ricci) and the Hessian Horseman (played by Christopher Walken). Understanding these relationships and their roles in the narrative can enhance comprehension of the film's plot and themes.

6. **Cinematic Style**:
   - The mention of Burton's directorial style and the influence of classic horror actors like Christopher Lee and Vincent Price suggests a specific aesthetic and thematic approach to the film, which may be unfamiliar to those who only know the basic premise of "Sleepy Hollow."

### Role of These Contents:
The extracted content serves several purposes:
- **Contextual Understanding**: It provides a richer context for the character of Ichabod Crane, allowing for a deeper understanding of his motivations and the film's narrative structure.
- **Character Complexity**: By highlighting Ichabod's quirks and backstory, it emphasizes the complexity of his character, which is essential for analyzing his role in the film.
- **Artistic Choices**: Insights into Depp's inspirations and the collaborative process with Burton reveal how artistic decisions shape character portrayals in film.
- **Thematic Exploration**: The references to supporting characters and the film's stylistic influences open avenues for discussing broader themes such as fear, trauma, and the intersection of science and superstition.

Overall, this background knowledge enriches the model's understanding of the question regarding Johnny Depp's role as Ichabod Crane in "Sleepy Hollow," enabling a more nuanced response.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question about which film Johnny Depp played a policeman called Ichabod Crane, I will analyze the relevant information provided in the passages and integrate additional context to enhance understanding.

1. **Character Identification**: Ichabod Crane is a character from Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow." In the film adaptation, he is portrayed as a New York City policeman, which is a significant departure from the original story where he is depicted as a schoolteacher. This modernized interpretation allows for a unique blend of horror and detective genres.

2. **Film Context and Direction**: The film "Sleepy Hollow," directed by Tim Burton and released in 1999, is known for its gothic aesthetic and stylized storytelling. Burton's direction often includes elements of dark fantasy, which aligns with the eerie themes of the original tale. The film's atmosphere and visual style contribute to its interpretation of the story.

3. **Character Traits and Development**: Ichabod Crane, as portrayed by Depp, is characterized as "quirky" and "sympathetic," with a strong interest in forensic science. His squeamishness about blood and death adds depth to his character, making him relatable. The backstory involving his mother's murder by his father provides insight into his psychological struggles and motivations, enhancing the narrative complexity.

4. **Collaboration and Artistic Choices**: Depp's collaboration with Tim Burton is significant, as they have worked together on multiple projects. Depp's approach to Ichabod Crane was influenced by various actors and performances, which shaped his portrayal to be more nuanced than a typical action hero. This artistic choice reflects a deeper exploration of the character's psyche.

5. **Supporting Characters and Narrative**: The film features important supporting characters, such as Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) and the Hessian Horseman (Christopher Walken). Their roles are integral to the plot and Ichabod's journey, providing additional layers to the story and illustrating themes of love, betrayal, and fear.

6. **Thematic Elements**: The film explores themes such as the clash between science and superstition, the nature of fear, and the impact of trauma. These themes are reflected in Ichabod's character arc and his investigation into the supernatural events in Sleepy Hollow.

By synthesizing this information, I can better understand the significance of Johnny Depp's role as Ichabod Crane and the film's broader implications.

### Answer:
Johnny Depp played the role of Ichabod Crane in the film "Sleepy Hollow," directed by Tim Burton and released in 1999. In this adaptation, Ichabod is portrayed as a New York City policeman with a keen interest in forensic science, sent to investigate a series of murders in the eerie town of Sleepy Hollow.

His character is also marked by a deep-seated fear of blood and death, which adds complexity to his role as a detective.

The film reinterprets Crane's character, providing a backstory that includes trauma from his childhood, which shapes his personality and investigative style. This backstory enriches the narrative and provides motivation for his actions throughout the film.

6. **Cultural Impact**: The portrayal of Ichabod Crane in "Sleepy Hollow" has become iconic, influencing how the character is perceived in popular culture. The film's blend of horror, humor, and gothic elements has made it a notable entry in the genre.

In summary, the passages provide a comprehensive view of Johnny Depp's role as Ichabod Crane in "Sleepy Hollow," highlighting the character's unique traits, the film's context, and the collaborative efforts between Depp and Burton. **Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

To answer the question regarding the film in which Johnny Depp played a policeman named Ichabod Crane, I will analyze the character's background, the film's context, and Depp's performance, while also considering the broader implications of the film within popular culture.

1. **Character Background**: Ichabod Crane is a character from Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow." In the 1999 film "Sleepy Hollow," directed by Tim Burton, Depp's portrayal of Crane is as a quirky New York City policeman who is ahead of his time, particularly in his interest in forensic science. This modern approach to crime-solving contrasts sharply with the more traditional methods of law enforcement during the story's setting, which adds depth to his character. His fear of blood and death introduces a layer of vulnerability, making him a more relatable and complex protagonist.

2. **Film Context**: "Sleepy Hollow" is not just a straightforward adaptation of Irving's tale; it reinterprets the story with a gothic aesthetic and a deeper exploration of Crane's psyche. The film delves into Crane's traumatic childhood, where he witnessed his mother's murder, which informs his character's motivations and fears. This backstory enriches the narrative and provides a compelling reason for his investigative methods and his emotional struggles.

3. **Performance and Inspiration**: Depp's performance is characterized by a blend of humor and emotional depth. He drew inspiration from various actors and performances, aiming to create a character that is both delicate and fragile. This approach diverges from the typical portrayal of action heroes, emphasizing emotional complexity and vulnerability. Depp's interpretation allows audiences to connect with Crane on a more personal level, enhancing the film's impact.

4. **Collaboration with Tim Burton**: The film represents Depp's third collaboration with Tim Burton, a partnership known for its unique visual style and character-driven narratives. Burton's direction complements Depp's performance, focusing on creating an atmosphere that blends horror and humor, which is a hallmark of their collaborations. This synergy is crucial in bringing the character of Ichabod Crane to life in a way that resonates with audiences.

5. **Supporting Characters**: The film features a strong supporting cast, including Christina Ricci as Katrina Van Tassel and Christopher Walken as the Hessian Horseman. Their roles are integral to the story, providing additional layers to Ichabod's character and the overall narrative. The interactions between these characters help to highlight Ichabod's struggles and growth throughout the film.

6. **Cultural Impact**: "Sleepy Hollow" has left a lasting impact on popular culture, influencing how the character of Ichabod Crane is perceived. The film's blend of horror, humor, and gothic elements has made it a notable entry in the genre, and Depp's portrayal has become iconic. This adaptation has contributed to the ongoing fascination with the character and the story, ensuring its relevance in contemporary discussions of horror and folklore.

In summary, the film "Sleepy Hollow" is a rich adaptation that explores the complexities of Ichabod Crane through Johnny Depp's nuanced performance. The character's unique traits, the film's gothic context, and the collaborative efforts between Depp and Burton all contribute to a deeper understanding of the narrative and its cultural significance.

**Answer: Sleepy Hollow**

The Hammer influence was further confirmed by the casting of Christopher Lee in a small role as the Burgomaster who sends Crane to Sleepy Hollow.\n', 'BULLET::::- Constable Ichabod Crane serves as the protagonist in the 1999 film adaptation of "Sleepy Hollow", directed by Tim Burton and starring Johnny Depp. In this interpretation, he is a New York City policeman with an interest in Forensic science sent to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a series of grisly murders to prove the merits of his style of the investigation after he argues against the police\'s current methods. As in the original story, his horse is named Gunpowder. Ichabod\'s most notable traits in the movie include an ahead-of-his-time liking for post-mortem examinations, deduction, and scientific methods, as well as his being very quirky, skittish, and being disturbed by death and blood, despite his occupation. His backstory is also explored: when he was seven his mother, an "innocent child of Nature" was "murdered to save her soul" by his father, "a Bible black tyrant behind a mask of righteousness" which led to a loss of faith for him. It is Ichabod who finally releases the Hessian Headless Horseman (Christopher Walken) from the control of Lady van Tassel (Miranda Richardson), whom the Horseman takes to Hell with him. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) is seen at the end of the movie going back to New York with Ichabod, along with a boy who helped him in the investigation. Brom Bones (Casper Van Dien), who at one point does disguise himself as the Horseman and throws a pumpkin at Ichabod, is killed by the real Horseman halfway in the film.\n', 'Depp\'s next venture with Burton was the period film "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), in which he played Ichabod Crane opposite Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken. For his performance, Depp took inspiration from Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall and Basil Rathbone. He stated that he "always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl."\n', 'BULLET::::- Ichabod Crane is also featured in the 2013 episodic video game, "The Wolf Among Us", developed and produced by Telltale Games. In the game, Crane (voiced by Roger L. Jackson) is the deputy mayor of Fabletown, a secret community of magical, fairytale beings who were exiled from their Homelands centuries ago and forced to live in the world of mundane humans. In episodes 2 through three, Crane was revealed to have been soliciting prostitutes and using a magic spell to make them look like his assistant Snow White; Sheriff Bigby Wolf and Snow arrest Crane for this and embezzling Fabletown\'s money to pay for them, but Crane is then kidnapped by the minions of the Crooked Man, the crime lord Crane owes money to.\n']

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
In which film did Johnny Depp play a policeman called Ichabod Crane?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- Johnny Depp as Ichabod Crane: Crane is a quirky, yet sympathetic constable infatuated with integrating modern science into police procedures, but is squeamish at the sight of blood and bugs. Depp is humorous in his portrayal of the character.\n', 'While Johnny Depp was Burton\'s first choice for the role of Ichabod Crane, Paramount required him to consider Brad Pitt, Liam Neeson and Daniel Day-Lewis. Depp was cast in July 1998 for his third collaboration with Burton. The actor wanted Ichabod to parallel Irving\'s description of the character in the short story. This included a long prosthetic snipe nose, huge ears, and elongated fingers. Paramount turned down his suggestions, and after Depp read Tom Stoppard\'s rewrite of the script, he was inspired to take the character even further. "I always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl," Depp explained. He did not wish to portray the character as a typical action star would have, and instead took inspiration by Angela Lansbury\'s performance in "Death on the Nile". "It\'s good," Burton reasoned, "because I\'m not the greatest action director in the world, and he\'s not the greatest action star." Depp modeled Ichabod\'s detective personality from Basil Rathbone in the 1939 "Sherlock Holmes" film series. He also studied Roddy McDowall\'s acting for additional influence. Burton added that "the idea was to try to find an elegance in action of the kind that Christopher Lee or Peter Cushing or Vincent Price had." Christina Ricci, who worked with producer Scott Rudin on "The Addams Family", was cast as Katrina Van Tassel. "Sleepy Hollow" also reunited Burton with Jeffrey Jones (from "Beetlejuice" and "Ed Wood") as Reverend Steenwyck, Christopher Walken (Max Shreck in "Batman Returns") as the Hessian Horseman, Martin Landau ("Ed Wood") in a cameo role, and Hammer veteran Michael Gough (Alfred in Burton\'s "Batman" films), whom Burton tempted out of retirement. The Hammer influence was further confirmed by the casting of Christopher Lee in a small role as the Burgomaster who sends Crane to Sleepy Hollow.\n', 'BULLET::::- Constable Ichabod Crane serves as the protagonist in the 1999 film adaptation of "Sleepy Hollow", directed by Tim Burton and starring Johnny Depp. In this interpretation, he is a New York City policeman with an interest in Forensic science sent to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a series of grisly murders to prove the merits of his style of the investigation after he argues against the police\'s current methods. As in the original story, his horse is named Gunpowder. Ichabod\'s most notable traits in the movie include an ahead-of-his-time liking for post-mortem examinations, deduction, and scientific methods, as well as his being very quirky, skittish, and being disturbed by death and blood, despite his occupation. His backstory is also explored: when he was seven his mother, an "innocent child of Nature" was "murdered to save her soul" by his father, "a Bible black tyrant behind a mask of righteousness" which led to a loss of faith for him. It is Ichabod who finally releases the Hessian Headless Horseman (Christopher Walken) from the control of Lady van Tassel (Miranda Richardson), whom the Horseman takes to Hell with him. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) is seen at the end of the movie going back to New York with Ichabod, along with a boy who helped him in the investigation. Brom Bones (Casper Van Dien), who at one point does disguise himself as the Horseman and throws a pumpkin at Ichabod, is killed by the real Horseman halfway in the film.\n', 'Depp\'s next venture with Burton was the period film "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), in which he played Ichabod Crane opposite Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken. For his performance, Depp took inspiration from Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall and Basil Rathbone. He stated that he "always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl."\n', 'BULLET::::- Ichabod Crane is also featured in the 2013 episodic video game, "The Wolf Among Us", developed and produced by Telltale Games. In the game, Crane (voiced by Roger L. Jackson) is the deputy mayor of Fabletown, a secret community of magical, fairytale beings who were exiled from their Homelands centuries ago and forced to live in the world of mundane humans. In episodes 2 through three, Crane was revealed to have been soliciting prostitutes and using a magic spell to make them look like his assistant Snow White; Sheriff Bigby Wolf and Snow arrest Crane for this and embezzling Fabletown\'s money to pay for them, but Crane is then kidnapped by the minions of the Crooked Man, the crime lord Crane owes money to.\n']

question_info.question: In which film did Johnny Depp play a policeman called Ichabod Crane?
passages:
BULLET::::- Johnny Depp as Ichabod Crane: Crane is a quirky, yet sympathetic constable infatuated with integrating modern science into police procedures, but is squeamish at the sight of blood and bugs. Depp is humorous in his portrayal of the character.
While Johnny Depp was Burton's first choice for the role of Ichabod Crane, Paramount required him to consider Brad Pitt, Liam Neeson and Daniel Day-Lewis. Depp was cast in July 1998 for his third collaboration with Burton. The actor wanted Ichabod to parallel Irving's description of the character in the short story. This included a long prosthetic snipe nose, huge ears, and elongated fingers. Paramount turned down his suggestions, and after Depp read Tom Stoppard's rewrite of the script, he was inspired to take the character even further. "I always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl," Depp explained. He did not wish to portray the character as a typical action star would have, and instead took inspiration by Angela Lansbury's performance in "Death on the Nile". "It's good," Burton reasoned, "because I'm not the greatest action director in the world, and he's not the greatest action star." Depp modeled Ichabod's detective personality from Basil Rathbone in the 1939 "Sherlock Holmes" film series. He also studied Roddy McDowall's acting for additional influence. Burton added that "the idea was to try to find an elegance in action of the kind that Christopher Lee or Peter Cushing or Vincent Price had." Christina Ricci, who worked with producer Scott Rudin on "The Addams Family", was cast as Katrina Van Tassel. "Sleepy Hollow" also reunited Burton with Jeffrey Jones (from "Beetlejuice" and "Ed Wood") as Reverend Steenwyck, Christopher Walken (Max Shreck in "Batman Returns") as the Hessian Horseman, Martin Landau ("Ed Wood") in a cameo role, and Hammer veteran Michael Gough (Alfred in Burton's "Batman" films), whom Burton tempted out of retirement. The Hammer influence was further confirmed by the casting of Christopher Lee in a small role as the Burgomaster who sends Crane to Sleepy Hollow.
BULLET::::- Constable Ichabod Crane serves as the protagonist in the 1999 film adaptation of "Sleepy Hollow", directed by Tim Burton and starring Johnny Depp. In this interpretation, he is a New York City policeman with an interest in Forensic science sent to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a series of grisly murders to prove the merits of his style of the investigation after he argues against the police's current methods. As in the original story, his horse is named Gunpowder. Ichabod's most notable traits in the movie include an ahead-of-his-time liking for post-mortem examinations, deduction, and scientific methods, as well as his being very quirky, skittish, and being disturbed by death and blood, despite his occupation. His backstory is also explored: when he was seven his mother, an "innocent child of Nature" was "murdered to save her soul" by his father, "a Bible black tyrant behind a mask of righteousness" which led to a loss of faith for him. It is Ichabod who finally releases the Hessian Headless Horseman (Christopher Walken) from the control of Lady van Tassel (Miranda Richardson), whom the Horseman takes to Hell with him. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) is seen at the end of the movie going back to New York with Ichabod, along with a boy who helped him in the investigation. Brom Bones (Casper Van Dien), who at one point does disguise himself as the Horseman and throws a pumpkin at Ichabod, is killed by the real Horseman halfway in the film.
Depp's next venture with Burton was the period film "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), in which he played Ichabod Crane opposite Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken. For his performance, Depp took inspiration from Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall and Basil Rathbone. He stated that he "always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl."
BULLET::::- Ichabod Crane is also featured in the 2013 episodic video game, "The Wolf Among Us", developed and produced by Telltale Games. In the game, Crane (voiced by Roger L. Jackson) is the deputy mayor of Fabletown, a secret community of magical, fairytale beings who were exiled from their Homelands centuries ago and forced to live in the world of mundane humans. In episodes 2 through three, Crane was revealed to have been soliciting prostitutes and using a magic spell to make them look like his assistant Snow White; Sheriff Bigby Wolf and Snow arrest Crane for this and embezzling Fabletown's money to pay for them, but Crane is then kidnapped by the minions of the Crooked Man, the crime lord Crane owes money to.
